{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3742518,"name":"chrisrin","username":"chrisrin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chrisrin/{size}/160418_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-19T04:48:35.199Z","cooked":"

We’re losing a portion of our storage and need to clear out stuff we don’t use, including several boxes of brushed motors (+ a couple Dynamos). It seems like we’re more or less past brushed motors as a competition… Or at least the worldwide supply in team inventories WAY exceeds the total number of these motors that will ever be used on robots again.

So we’re at a point (past it for some teams, I’m sure) where, if there isn’t some scalable solution to redistribute these motors to people who would use them (tinkerers, etc.), we’re going to end up dumping 10s, maybe 100s of thousands of them, which seems like such a waste. “Scalable” redistribution seems key, because no one has time to find new homes for these things 1 or 2 at a time.

Have there been any great local ideas that might scale? Like everybody bring your old motors to competition and “someone” takes them for redistribution (sell them for dirt cheap to hobbiests?)? Is the value there for something like that to be worth the time?

I know it’s probably a lost cause, but in my brain I’m seeing disappointed looks on my (long since passed) depression era grandparents’ faces when I think about having to dump these things. Thanks!

I do recommend always keeping at least 10 Brushed motors somewhere in your shop. A few CIMs and 775 Pros and 2 Bags is what we got.

  • Sometimes you need a motor for a prototype that’s a bit more powerful or need it to fit in a spot where a drill can’t, but you can’t be bothered to use a brushless motor and all the setup / controls that entails.

As far as recycling from 100s down to the few you keep, some quick googling shows various places that take motors and scrap them for the copper wire and aluminum housings. Perhaps there’s one near you. Each year I take 254’s dead batteries to a recycling plant that looks straight out of Mad Max, but we earn $20 and it makes for a fun story.

2 of my points somehow got lost when I was trying to edit and fix a typo. Maybe a mod can restore? I forgot exactly what I had nicely written

Something about donating motors to students for projects and us also using to donate to teams via our Cheesy Care team.

https://theredalliance.net/ is a place where we donate parts that we no longer use. Their mission is to provide these parts (free of charge) to teams that need them. We also collect parts at events we are at, so other teams can donate that way as well (unfortunately, our paths likely don’t cross).

I’m not sure if shipping parts across the country is reasonable or not (though I know from talking the person who founded this activity, they have shipped parts to various locations outside of US, so maybe shipping costs aren’t an issue. They have a contact link on their website, so you could ask).

As someone who’s studying ME in college, you might be able to sell them to the local college’s engineering department for a small amount – the college probably will have an archaic purchasing system and you will need to work with a professor to get your money but I’m currently in a class where my professor does have some interest in obtaining a bunch of cheap motors. They may also be interested in taking failed components for analysis (although this may just be one of the quirks of one of my professors).

Worth asking if you have a connection, tbh.

Honestly I would just take it to whatever nearest scrap metal recycling place (that accepts motors) is near you if you can’t find anywhere to sell/donate it to, similar to what @torrance said. However, I wouldn’t even bother keeping them cause we have a small-ish pile of cims and other brushed motors collecting dust cause we never used them once after we ended up with a large amount of neos and sparkmaxes.
